text: From notes. Enjoyed at Corbets house warming on April 23. 750 mL bottle courtesy of Corbet. The pour is a light hazy yellow straw color with a thicker white head that falls down to a thin film pretty quickly. The aroma is light and clean. There is a light wine barrel up front with a hint of spiciness and a lightly floral hop. The hops are crisp, and really lend themselves to the other aspects. There is a light fruitiness to it, but the wine barrel does mute a fair bit of this. The flavor is excellent. The light wheatiness comes through with a hint of spice and a lingering tart hoppiness. The barrel is prevalent and balances out lovely with the winey grapes that are light and delicate. This is just so balanced and clean. The mouth feel is light and crisp with a bright carbonation and a lingeringly tart and clean wine barrel spiciness. Jesus. This is just spectacular.

Bottle at Leightons 20k, massive thanks to the main man himself. It pours hazy pale gold with a small white head. The aroma is fresh, fragrant, vinous, white grape, elderflower, wood, straw and soft creaminess. The taste is crisp, dry, gooseberry, white grape, green apple, vanilla, straw, oak, orange peel, kumquat, mango, pepper and a touch of alcohol. Medium body and fine carabontion. All comes together rather well. Very enjoyable stuff.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!

The beer is hazy yellow with a small white collar. Aromas of citrus, funk, lemon, grass, spice, floral hops. Zesty, juicy, floral. Delicious. Elegant balance. Tangy and quaffable. Damn, this is tasty.

Thanks Brad for sharing the bottle! Poured into a taster showing unfiltered whitish yellow with a sparse white foam lacing. 

The nose shows clean saison forwardness with a background of dark red wine. 

The palate is medium bodied and moderately carbonated. Flavors of light apricot, lime, and a white wine bitterness.

March 1st 2017Leightons 20K at his posh new gaff! Big thanks to our host and main artery to this much regarded brewery. Hazy gold beer, short lived white head. Palate is smooth and semi dry, decent fine carbonation. A mild gueuzey sourness offset by winey floralness and winey tangy fruits. Light finish. Pretty drinkable. HF Saisons never really set fireworks off for me but this one is nice.

St Davids Day 2017 - Bottle share at Leightons 20K. Many congrats and thanks! As Hill Farmstead Dorothy - Wine Barrel Aged. Pours hazy golden orange, still with a foamy off-white head, leaving streaky lacing. Aroma has fruity white wine up front, some spearmint, more green grape. Body is light, a bit frothy with tingly carbonation. Taste is white wine and spearmint, minerally, oak, lime squash, grape and elderflower. A rounded and very drinkable, enjoyable offering. Cheers! (4.0)

75cl bottle shared at Leightons Penthouse for his 20K. Special thanks to Leighton himself for this beer. It pours a clean golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is intensely tangy acidic with notes of lemon juice, melon, funk, white wine. Taste is also windy acidic, lemon juice, melon, straw, lemon peel, some funk and more gooseberries. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, very good

Bottle shared at the Leighton mega 20k tasting. 1/03/2017. Huge thanks to Leighton for this one. A hazed golden yellow coloured pour with a lasting white head. Aroma is juicy, grapey fruits, apricot, light funky yeast, nice saison yeast. Little pithy lemon citrus. Flavour is composed of tart grapey, vinous fruits, apricot, lemon citrus, peach, white stone fruits, lychee. Palate is tart and refreshing, moderate carbonation. Lovely. Really nice tart fruit.

Bottle shared in London during the 20k - sourced via trade. Pours clear yellow-gold with a creamy, white head. Glorious aroma, some citrus, peach, mellow brett funk, hay, grapefruit. Light sweet flavour with mild acidity, more juicy citrus, tangerine, peach, a little woody dryness, pine needles. Light bodied with delicate carbonation. Great balance in the finish, super refreshing, some pine, more citrus, peach, grapefruit, melon, understated wheat, some background farm funk. A little acidic burn in the aftertaste. Wonderful.

Bottle shared at Leighton 20k tasting. Thanks to mein host. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma has a white wine edge, a little funk and grape. Taste is really subtle, funky with a lovely fresh wine edge. Really good stuff

Bottle courtesy of Jacob. Hazy tiny burnt yellow with a big frothy white head. Explosive amazing fruity funky nose with tons of yellow tropical fruits, white grapes, hay, barnyard, dry wood & minerals. Tiny sour, tiny bitter, fruity & funky taste. Insane funky yellow tropical fruits. Adding the Hill Farmstead barrel funk to regular plain but delicious Dorothy makes it one of the best beers Iäve ever had. Just so damn delicious!

A: Cloudy deep yellow colured with a thin white lacing N: Pear, honeydew, grapefruit zest, farmhouse T: Honeydew, peach, pear, red apples, grapefruit zest O: Wow! Very complex and very fruity! Lovely!
Bottle. Pours cloudy pale amber with a small head. Aroma is fruity funky slightly citric grainy. Flavor is refreshing citrucy malty/grainy funky sourish nicely bitter and a bit woody astringent

(Bouteille provenant de la brasserie): Bonne acidité de fruit à noyau en arôme mais aussi très juteux pour compenser. Une sauvagerie grasse domestique également laspect citrique qui ne tranche pratiquement plus au final. Harmonieux, vineux, pulpeux et surtout pas surfait. Délectable.
Bottle from trade. Drank with a bunch of HF and it was tasty. Minerals, white wine, slightly tart. Just great.

750ml bottle drank in a cabin in the woods in Stanstead. Aroma: awesome vinous nose of white grapes, lots of flowers and citrus mostly lemon zest, light herbs. App: clear pale goldenish, small white head leaving little lacing. Taste and palate: light body, oily / resinous, clementines in mouth, subtle acidity finish. Overall: honestly would have never guessed the base was Dorothy. Mouthfeel is all in finesse. Could give the impression of being boring but its really not. Its just really easy to drink. Awesome stuff. A treat.
C hopped aroma. Opaque yellow with lace story. Yes, a saison like other HF saisons. Nelson Citra like hop taste and aroma.

Gold pour, hazy, larger head. White wine, grape, oak, yeast, slightly catty, citrus aroma. Nelson and citra hops give way to yeast, oak, white wine, white grape. Slight catty taste. Lighter body, drying mouthfeel. Stellar

750 ml bottle shared by seeswo or urbancaver- not sure which one brought it, but thanks, guys! Pours a hazy white wine color with a small white head that settles almost immediately. Notes of melon, white wine, lemon, oak, florals, farmhouse funk, and apricot. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a funky, vinous, tart mouthfeel. Delicate on the palate, just really nice and pleasant.

Shared bottle, poured a hazy golden colour with a white head. Nose of citrus fruits, light malts, white grapes, incredible juicy wine aroma like all barrel aged Hill farmstead saisons, subtle sweet oak, still Some dry hop notes from the base, light malt profile, sweet juicy wine aftertaste. Delicious like always

Bottle from jamesy -- cheers! Im a sucker for the magic that happens when Hill Farmstead ages their beer in wine barrels, so it was no surprise that I was blown away by this beer. Tried side-by-side with Dorothy, and the difference was stark. While regular Dorothy is hoppy and fruity from the Brett yeast, the barrel-aged version is soft, with a lot of green apple and white wine flavors. BA Dorothy, as a dry-hopped beer, has more hop bitterness than Art or Flora, but it definitely works a lot more than E.. Phenomenally good beer.

750ml bottle @ Alexs. Pours a haze blond with thin white head. Nose is wine, wild yeast, oak, and some fruits. Flavour is of wine, fruits, wild yeast, with a slight bitter finish. Wow this is tasty. Love those nose.
Bottle - Bright citrus and nice light barrel. Cloudy golden yellow with a small white head. Bright citrus and a light touch of acidity. Absurdly juicy, maybe too much but still very nice.

750mL bottle, sent from yourilevesque (thanks a lot, Youri), pours a cloudy light golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out lovely dry hopping notes, apricot-y stone fruits, and a touch of wine. Flavour is very multi-dimensional, with a wonderful mix of dry hopping and stone fruits (specifically apricot). I dont get any wine or barrels on this. Wonderful complexity, bringing out a great marriage of dry hopping and stone fruits. Fantastic stuff.

Courtesy of MattHazy blond color, small head. The aroma is vinous, a bit funky, sour, flowery, with hints of vanilla. Soft mouthfeel, the flavor is crisp, a bit lemony, salty, with hints of acetic acid.Excellent.

Pours a hazy golden colour with a thin head. Aroma of tropical fruit and a touch of piney hops. Tastes of mango, mild passionfruit, and a bit of mandarin orange. I wouldnt have guessed wine barrel aged, but damn, this is mighty fine.

Yummy !!! Thanks N8daGr8 for snagging this on a birthday run to VT and sharing it with my lazy cellar dwelling selections. Pours a hazy golden yellow with two finger of white foam. Nose is a mix of tropical hop notes, pineapple, mango, clementine all wrapped in a soft floral field grain base with some juicy vinous notes riding below. Juicy, funky chuggable. Everything I like about beer in one glass of harmony !

Bottle 750ml.
Pours blond with low white head. Aroma is of pepper, wild yeast, fruits, oak. Taste is of fruits, pepper, wild yeast, wine, yogurt. Palate: Medium body, medium carbonation. Overall: Very nice stuff. Fruity. Awesome barrel action.

Bottle. Pours a lightly hazed pale yellow with a white head. Some spots of lacing half way through. Aromas of citrus, faded sticky hops, signature restrained HF funk. Taste is similar. Moderately bitter. A more elegant, lightly funky version of Dorothy. Light+ to medium bodied; lightly dry finish.

Bottle shared by tom10101, many thanks again bro! Pours a light golden and pretty clear with a thin white head plus rim that leaves low lacing. Nose is of white wine, flowers, oak, pepper, dill and is extremely satisfying. Taste plays on the same theme (white wine, lightly dilly, oaky) but this time there is a light fruity tartness and some distant pale cereals in the back. Moderate body and carbonation with a nice vinous mouthfeel, just so easy to drink! A great barrel-aged saison! Its hard to improve on the "regular" Dorothy but this one blew me away!
Bottle shared. Hazy gold pour with thin white head. Aroma is super citrusy, really nice wine, super grassy. Taste is tart, very citrusy, light grassy notes, soft oak. Great.

Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a cloudy yellow gold with small frothy white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is grape, funk, oak, citrus. Medium body, juicy, citrus, oak, nice tartness, really enjoyed this.

Bottle (750 ml), shared. Thanks to stoned99! Slightly hazy green-ish golden with a small white head leaving little lacing. Aroma is winey with lime, mineral notes, pickles, grassy hops and brettanomyces. Taste is winey with lime, mineral notes, brettanomyces, pickles, grass and mild spiciness. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Winey mouthfeel. Fruity finish. Very nice barrel-aged version of Dorothy. Tasty stuff.

bottle shared by tom10101, many thanks bro! pours hazy/cloudy very light golden with a small white cap, offering some retention and lacing. fresh nectarines, peppery fragrant honeydew melons, citrusy flowers, woodsy barrel, light acidity - complex flora with a pinch of acetic acid, never disturbing, rather complementing; very fruity and zesty saaaizohn yeast, salt. moderate carbonation, light body, tart woodsy-citrusy finish. juicy, winey and pleasantly tart. excellent stuff!

Bottle courtesy of Paul, shared with Max and Vinny. Pours a cloudy, bright yellow body with thick active white lacing. Nose is tart oak, sour fruits, wine, minerals and soft lime. Mouthfeel is spot on - nearly perfect, typical Hill Farm funky culture, sour citrus fruits, lime minerals, tart tropical notes - some passion fruit as it warms. Incredible, and still probably room to improve with age.
Bottle. Hazy funky yellow pour, with white head. Funky, wine, yeast, white grapes, aromas. Flavors are funky, fruity, white wine grapes, oak, sweet tones.
Bottle - pours yellow white head - nose and taste of lemon, wine, nectarine, grapefruit, funky oak, spicy yeast - medium body

Bottle from Paul, thanks dude. Pours cloudy yellow gold. Smell is graham, heavy oak, and vanilla.... a touch young in the scent. Flavor is a whole different story, sour lemon, grape skinnage, grapefruit, passionfruit and melon minerals. This will be insane fire in 6 months but shes already a champion

750ml bottle split two ways at fridge temp. Allowed to be stored upright for a few weeks but the beer did not really clarify. Its still a burnt golden hazy color. 1 finger head that faded fast. 

This smells amazing. Its distinctively Dorothy. Citra, juicy, tropical bright and theres a wine presence and Brett funkiness. Wow. 

Excellent mouthfeel. Its perfect. 

The flavor, its loaded with a ruby red grapefruit acidity. Oranges, a bit of tannic oak. Its actually pretty thick. A little lemon juice and grape skins. It has this flavor thats reminiscent of the most recent batch of E. Which makes a lot of sense

Theres no doubt this is Dorothy. Its just better.

750 mL bottle. Hazy yellow. Aroma is earthy brett, very light wine, some citrus hops. Tastes has a lot more white wine. Brett cuts the sweetness of the wine. Light lemon tartness. Bitter finish. Light body. Ive never been the biggest fan of Dorothy because of the abrasive character of the brett. The white wine lends sweetness and just a little bit of acidity that make this very pleasant.

Bottle. Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Brett and wine barrel bouquet. Wow, this beer is delicious. Wine barrel notes add balance and depth to the lemon zest and mildly bitter grassy hops. Really good body and mouthfeel.

750ml bottle at hill farmstead. Pours out a nice golden topped with a small head. Nose is big wine barrel notes white grapes oak lemon citrus saison spice. Taste is more of the heavy white wine barrel treatment very nice with the lemon zest tartness. This was very well done.

Un grand merci à Marc-André pour l partage! Bonne fête mec! Un produit la fois très près et très loin de Mère Dorothy. Robe jaune paille et chapeau de bulles maculé et blanc comme neige formé de grosses bulles persistantes et collantes. Liquide voilé, palais saillant. Un nez où lon reconnaît parfaitement Dorothy. Un houblonnage à cru important qui laisse échapper des arômes citronnées auxquelles sajoutent à cette version de la bière, des notes funky, boisées et riches. La barrique était visiblement pleine de vin blanc car je sens et je goûte une texture qui me rappelle le Chardonnay de par son côté buttery et gras en bouche. Le citron a beau trancher sur le funk longtemps entretenu en barrique, lamertume est réelle et le bois puissant. Une bière qui accompagne parfaitement cette pizza aux fruits de mer danniversaire mais que jaurais sans doute eu beaucoup de mal à déguster autrement.

Bottle shared with Nelson at the brewery, 7/8/16.Perfect appearance as expected. Huge white head is well-retained atop a blonde-copper-brass body with a gentle haze, at most, and plentiful carbonation.The beautiful, clear brett of Dorothy is here in full force, though perhaps even more softened/refined from its time in the barrel. Immediately reminds of E., oddly enough, though its cleaner and more delicate, perhaps. Barrel character is reserved and its possible to imagine some wine notes, but theyre very light at best. Plentiful fruitiness; lime, nectarine, lemon and light pineapple all dance about on the nose with very light, soft honey and biscuit-like malts in the background. Rustic, charming house character adds plentiful minerality, completing the picture of a wonderfully hoppy, brett-filled, modestly funky, farmhouse beer. No alcohol or flaw.Exquisitely tight carbonation, as HFs best beers always exhibit softly spreads delicate, lemon-lime-like brett tartness about the palate. Soft, biscuit-tinged malts divulge more honey with warming, helping balance the acidity, though the beer never gets more than pleasantly tart. Juicy, lightly tropical and floral notes emanate from the hops, with low to moderate bitterness and a touch of wood at points, as well as suggestions of wine, if one looks for them. Fantastic stuff, overdone in no aspect. Wonderful balance is one of the best qualities and what separates the best of the best from the rest, as I think it does here.Though I think barrel-aging is much over-hyped and over-used, I think the extra lagering it provides Dorothy here is actually highly beneficial in improving the beer, as I think Dorothy, like Arthur, can be a bit aggressive young.
